section.title: Solution: partitions
section.para: 1. Use fdisk -l to display existing partitions and sizes.
2. Use df -h to display existing partitions and sizes.
3. Compare the output of fdisk and df.
section.screen: Some partitions will be listed in both outputs (maybe /dev/sda1 or /dev/hda1).
section.para: 4. Create a 200MB primary partition on a small disk.
section.screen: Choose one of the disks you added (this example uses /dev/sdc)

root@rhel53 ~# fdisk /dev/sdc ... Command (m for help): n Command action e extended p primary partition (1-4) p Partition number (1-4): 1 First cylinder (1-261, default 1): 1 Last cylinder or +size or +sizeM or +sizeK (1-261, default 261): +200m
Command (m for help): w The partition table has been altered!
Calling ioctl() to re-read partition table. Syncing disks.
section.para: 5. Create a 400MB primary partition and two 300MB logical drives on a big disk.
section.screen: Choose one of the disks you added (this example uses /dev/sdb)
inside fdisk : n p 1 +400m enter --- n e 2 enter enter --- n l +300m (twice)
section.para: 6. Use df -h and fdisk -l to verify your work.
7. Compare the output again of fdisk and df. Do both commands display the new partitions ?
section.screen: The newly created partitions are visible with fdisk.
But they are not displayed by df.
section.para: 8. Create a backup with dd of the mbr that contains your 200MB primary partition.
9. Take a backup of the partition table containing your 400MB primary and 300MB logical drives. Make sure the logical drives are in the backup.
10. (optional) Remove all your partitions with fdisk. Then restore your backups.
